Award.AwardTitle: Doctoral Dissertation Research: Consumer Citizenship Among Internally Displaced Persons

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Division Of Behavioral and Cognitive Sci

Award.AbstractNarration:
The research supported by this award investigates the politics, routes of circulation, and patterns of consumption of material aid given to displaced people. This project asks three sets of research questions: (1) Aid provision: How do governments interpret and protect the social rights of its displaced citizens through the distribution of aid? What is the role of non-state aid providers in these processes? (2) Aid consumption: What kind of bureaucratic procedures do internally displaced people (IDPs) navigate to qualify for aid? How do IDPs consume material assistance? How does aid reinforce or dismantle IDPs' ideas about the state and belonging? (3) Aid circulation: Does the value of humanitarian aid change in the process of its circulation? What meanings does aid accrue in contexts of political ambivalence? The research is important because displacement is one of the biggest and fast-growing challenges in the contemporary world. While humanitarian aid in the wake of displacement is an entrenched feature of the modern world, including American foreign policy, the full range of effects is not well documented. Findings will be useful to policy makers concerned with making aid more effective and to social scientists building theories of the material aspects of contemporary citizenship.

The research will be conducted by Indiana University anthropology doctoral student Tetiana Bulakh, under the supervision of Dr. Sarah Phillips, focusing on IDPs in the Ukraine. This is an appropriate site because the Ukraine has one of the highest IDP populations in the world. The researcher will focus on officials who develop IDP policies, representatives of international organizations, local volunteers, and IDPs and their social networks. She will collect data using a mixed-methods approach, including interviews, participant observation, "social biographies" or tracking of aid objects, aid-focused interviews, projective tests, and analysis of archival documents related to IDP policy.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This award covered 12 months of ethnographic fieldwork research on humanitarian aid to internally displaced people (IDP) in Ukraine. Since 2014, conflict in Eastern Ukraine has forced more than 1.4 million people to leave their homes and become conflict-driven IDPs. For internally displaced people, humanitarian aid is not only a matter of addressing material needs, but also an issue of citizens’ rights to social protection and welfare as provided by the state. The data collected during the research documented the politics of governance, routes of circulation, and patterns of consumption of material aid by IDPs. Further analysis of fieldwork data will discuss how material aid is managed and how it is utilized is crucial for understanding the role of aid not only in rebuilding IDPs’ lives, but also in transformation of their citizens’ entitlements in times of conflict-induced crisis.

The fieldwork was conducted by Tetiana Bulakh, under the supervision of Dr. Sarah Phillips (Indiana University, Bloomington). During the field research, investigators collected two sets of data. The first set highlights humanitarian aid provision and circulation. This set encompasses archival and policy analysis, over 500 hours of participant observation and in-depth interviews with policy-makers and aid providers. The second ethnographic data set focuses on the consumption of aid. Drawing from unstructured in-depth interviews with displaced and conflict-affected people, researchers gathered information about IDPs’ understandings of their social rights and observed their use of aid.

This research documents important information of how different aid providers govern humanitarian aid and highlights what impacts aid have on the lives of displaced people. This project’s focus on material aid will potentially generate innovative solutions for humanitarian practitioners and policy-makers, thereby elucidating how the conditions of displaced persons may be more effectively alleviated for future crises of forced migration.
